item.title: My first day of java
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“cant touch this93, post:8, topic:83702”][quote author=lawl link=topic=122997.msg1207216#msg1207216 date=1177386915]

Why did you declare “final int ARRAY_SIZE = 5;” and never use it?

Because he’s learning. Anyway, if you’re using if statements, it’s probably best to get into a habit of opening and closing them with braces {}, even if it’s a single statement within the if statement. That way if you go back at a later date and add something, it won’t be bug prone.

nvr.
much cleaner without them, if its one line.
[/quote]

Does it effect the program if i use them or not,or does it just make it look good?[/quote]

It effects the program size if you compile it with LineNumberTable attributes

Read full topic

item.title: My first day of java
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“lawl, post:2, topic:84014”][quote author=lothy link=topic=122997.msg1206885#msg1206885 date=1177383603]

Why did you declare “final int ARRAY_SIZE = 5;” and never use it?

Because he’s learning. Anyway, if you’re using if statements, it’s probably best to get into a habit of opening and closing them with braces {}, even if it’s a single statement within the if statement. That way if you go back at a later date and add something, it won’t be bug prone.
[/quote]
nvr.
much cleaner without them, if its one line.[/quote]
That’s really a matter of opinion. I believe that’s fine if you have it all on a single line like this:

if(condition) doThis();

That is fine, because it is very easy to see that only one thing will be carried out should that condition return true.

However, something like this isn’t so good:

if(condition) doThis();
If the statement is set out like that, it should have braces. Especially if you develop code that is going to be added to by multiple people.
What happens if someone wants to add something to be carried out if that condition returns true? Something like this could take place:

if(conditon) doThis(); doStuff();
The developer could easily think that doStuff will only be called if condition returns true, but there are no braces there, meaning it will get called in all situations. That’s where programs can become bug prone if they’re evolving over time.

Oh, and with regards to nesting if statements, it doesn’t really matter. Again, it’s a matter of opinion.
This:

if(condition) { if(condition) { doThis(); } }

is no different to this:

if(condition && condition) { doThis(); }
However, nesting if statements instead of putting all conditions into a single if statement can allow more flexibility depending on what you’re doing.

I’d prefer something like this when working with string stuff:

if(str.length() > 2) { if(str.contains("@")) { System.out.println("String could be an email address"); } else { System.out.println("String is not an email address"); } } else { System.out.println("This string is too short"); }

instead of this:

if(str.length() > 2 && str.contains("@")) { System.out.println("String could be an email address"); } else if(!str.contains("@")) { System.out.println("String is not an email address"); } else { System.out.println("This string is too short"); }

Read full topic

item.description:
@cant_touch_this93 wrote:

By what Thatoneserver posted i think it looks cleaner if its jsut a few lines of code to not put them in…

if(statement1) { if(statement2) { declare1(); } } }

that looks messy and un organized…also…why must you add more than one } and the end of your code…is it t make it neat,spacing,or what?

Read full topic

item.title: My first day of java
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

It’s a personal preference.

And to be honest, I believe it’s cleaner to put braces.

And sometimes it’s good to have

if (condition1) { if (condition2) { } else { OMGANELSE(); } } else { OMGANOTHERELSE(); }

Read full topic

item.title: My first day of java
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

[quote=“cant touch this93, post:8, topic:83702”][quote author=lawl link=topic=122997.msg1207216#msg1207216 date=1177386915]

Why did you declare “final int ARRAY_SIZE = 5;” and never use it?

Because he’s learning. Anyway, if you’re using if statements, it’s probably best to get into a habit of opening and closing them with braces {}, even if it’s a single statement within the if statement. That way if you go back at a later date and add something, it won’t be bug prone.

nvr.
much cleaner without them, if its one line.
[/quote]

Does it effect the program if i use them or not,or does it just make it look good?[/quote]
It does not. In fact, It is a good habit not to use {}s unless you are declaring more than one line of code. Like. . .

If(statement) declareStuff()
looks much better than

if(statement) { declareStuff() }

Also, while we are on the topic,
Do not do this

if(statement1) { if(statement2) { declare1(); } } } just use

if(statement1 && statement2)

Not saying that you did, but i see lots of people who tend to do that, and it bothers me. . . Lol who ever made pvp mage(servers) was a messy coder.

Read full topic

item.title: My first day of java
item.dc:creator: @cant_touch_this93 cant touch this93
item.description:
@cant_touch_this93 wrote:

I watched about 25 minuutes of video tutorials and read some basic java stuff(mainly what int means and stuff like that)I had messed around with private servers before so i had a general idea of java. Heres what i have done so far.

[code]public class stringvar
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
String var1 = “joe”;
String var2 = “bob”;
String var1and2;
char varchar;
int stringLength;

	if (var2.equals(var1))
	 System.out.println(var1 + "  " + var2);
else
	System.out.println("the strings are not identical");
}

}
[/code]

[code]import java.util.*;

public class userInput
//user enters name and age
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
int intInput;
String stringInput;

	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.print("what is your name? ");
	stringInput = input.nextLine();

    System.out.print("What is your age? ");
	intInput = input.nextInt();

	input.close();

	System.out.print("Hello " + stringInput +
						".You are " +  intInput + " years old");


}[/code]

[code]import java.util.*;

//Student ages
public class StudentNumber
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{

	final int ARRAY_SIZE = 5;

	int[] studentAge = new int[5];
	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);


	for (int x = 0; x < studentAge.length; x++)
 	{
	System.out.print("enter age for student number "+ (x + 1) + ".");
	studentAge[x] = input.nextInt();
	}

	input.close();

	for(int x = 0; x < studentAge.length; x++)
	System.out.println("the student ages as are folows: " + studentAge[x]);

}
}[/code]

Day two
[code]class Cust
 {

	public static void main(String[] args)
	{

		Customer item1 = new Customer(12345,"Bob Joe",25);
		Customer item2 = new Customer(12345,"billy Joe",28);


		System.out.println(item1.getName() + " - " + item1.getRefNo() + " - " + item1.getAge());
		System.out.println(item2.getName() + " - " + item2.getRefNo() + " - " + item2.getAge());


	}

}

 public class Customer
{

	private int refNo;
	private String name;
	private int age;


	public Customer(int ErefNo, String Ename, int Eage)
	{
		refNo = ErefNo;
		name = Ename;
		age = Eage;
    }

	 public String getName()
	 {
		return name;

     }

     public int getRefNo()
     {
		 return refNo;
	 }

	 public int getAge()
	 {
	 	return age;

     }
     public String changeName(String Ename)
	 {
		return name;

     }

     public int chnageRefNo(int ErefNo)
     {
		 return refNo;
	 }

	 public int changeAge(int Eage)
	 {
	 	return age;
     }
}

[/code]
